Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory that has been very successful in describing a wide range of physical phenomena. However, its foundations have been a source of controversy for more than a century. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to quantum theory. Our approach is based on a set of axioms that guarantee that a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. This approach addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our results also have implications for the foundations of functional analysis.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in fish, amphibians, and mammals. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present evidence that the Myxozoa are a sister taxon to the cnidarian parasite Polypodium hydriforme. We also show that the Myxozoa have one of the smallest animal genomes reported to date. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The host immune response is a major factor in the control of SARS-CoV-2 infection. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to block nuclear import of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will increase the variability of crop yields. This study quantifies the magnitude of this increase and its consequences for global maize production. We find that the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most major maize-producing countries. This increase is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and to a decrease in mean yields. The probability that the top four maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Herbivores are essential components of ecosystems, but their impacts on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are poorly understood. This is partly because we lack a comprehensive understanding of how herbivores partition food resources. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These findings suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages. Our results also highlight the importance of species-level diet characterization in studies of herbivore ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a major environmental problem. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load is far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks. Plastic debris is first fragmented into smaller pieces, which are then transported to the ocean interior. There, they may be incorporated into food webs. This process may explain the missing plastic debris. Our results have important implications for the understanding of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago. This is an important step forward in understanding the origin of these grains.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels. It controls vascular function and is the first line of defense against infection. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells. These cells are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is critical for the endothelium to control vascular function and to respond to infection. Here, we show that the network is highly efficient in transmitting information. The network is also highly dynamic, allowing the endothelium to rapidly respond to infection. These findings provide insight into the design of the endothelial network. They also provide a foundation for understanding the role of the endothelium in cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are relevant for tracking the pandemic, and can be used to empower research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selectivity of the channel. The selectivity filter is also the most difficult part of the channel to study. We have identified a key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can collapse from an inactivated to a conductive conformation. This work provides a structural explanation for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural basis for the collapse of the selectivity filter. This collapse is a key step in the opening of the channel.

Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products. We identified 146 genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products in anaerobic gut fungi. We also identified 7 bacteriocins in anaerobic gut fungi. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products. This article is protected by copyright. Anxiety is a common psychiatric disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. Although anxiety is known to be associated with a number of negative consequences, such as impaired cognition and impaired social functioning, the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety influences social dominance in rats. We identified a key role for brain energy metabolism in mediating this effect. Our findings point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches. This article is protected by copyright. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in mechanical engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures with multiple material phases that can seamlessly collaborate to produce arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized and effectively manufactured. The responses are physically realized. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with heterogeneous materials and assembled architectures with complex behaviors. The strategy can be applied to design mechanical devices for various applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern is regulated by the transcription factor BCL11A. In this study, we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is a downstream element of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is developmentally silenced in erythroid tissues and that its overexpression in erythroid cells causes a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This phenotype is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. Our results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. Cancer treatment is often associated with severe side effects, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. This effect is mediated by the induction of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), which in turn protects cancer cells from ferroptosis. In preclinical models, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction showed therapeutic promise. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. Hypertension is also associated with aging. The use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers is increasing in the elderly population. We show that L-type Ca2+ channel blockers activate store-operated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells. Our data indicate that the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers should be carefully considered in the elderly population.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed forest management on 10 million hectares of federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but not early-seral–associated species. The NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests, and early-seral ecosystems are still declining. The NWFP is now 25 years old. We conclude that the NWFP has not been successful in reversing the decline of older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. We use computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome to screen a library of acylide antibiotics. We show that the best candidate is more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our approach can be used to identify new antibiotics for other pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. We show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. We show that periods of high lake level are observed during times of high eccentricity. The extreme hydroclimate variability exerted a profound influence on the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock; the geographically extensive habitat reconfiguration provided novel ecological opportunities

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book on a light-emitting device took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1,300-y period of abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YD cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YD boundary. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YD sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio is consistent with a terrestrial origin of Os. In contrast, the YD site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The spherules are likely ejecta from an impact 12.9 ka ago. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses. However, its role in the maintenance of tolerance is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. Moreover, we show that CTLA-4 deficiency can have opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. It also provides a model for studying the role of CTLA-4 in different diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We used a comprehensive dataset to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles and traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding. Our results suggest that beetles diversified in a world dominated by angiosperms, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes were key to the evolution of specialized plant feeding. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and treatments. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm to enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is the process by which cultural traits spread through a population. The extent to which larger populations enhance CCE is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE. This finding is important because it suggests that CCE may be more limited than previously thought. It also has implications for the evolution of human culture.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE is a multifunctional protein that is involved in lipid metabolism and the clearance of cellular debris. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of C1q accumulation in AD brain, suggesting that APOE may influence the rate of AD pathogenesis. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate AD pathogenesis by increasing the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. This hypothesis is supported by the finding that APOE4 increases the amount of C1q protein in AD brain. These studies may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the planet. The inner core is a mystery. The nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still unknown. The required undercooling for the inner core to nucleate is unrealistically low. This contradiction is called the inner core nucleation paradox. We use a persistent embryo method and molecular dynamics simulations to show that the bcc phase of iron has a higher nucleation rate than the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the paradox. This is the first time that the bcc phase has been shown to be the nucleation site of a solid phase. This work provides a new perspective on the origin of the inner core. It also provides a new way to understand the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This article is protected by copyright. Marijuana abuse is a major public health concern. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the underlying mechanisms are not. Here, we show that marijuana abusers have reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of addiction and the effects of marijuana abuse. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Language is the defining feature of humanity. Yet, despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also outperform humans on this task. We then show that these models’ neural fits generalize to other datasets and imaging modalities. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that we may be able to use machine learning to improve language processing in computers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep learning is a powerful machine-learning paradigm that has achieved unprecedented success in many applications. However, it is still unclear why deep networks are so effective. In this paper, we show that the instability of deep networks is closely related to the difficulty of solving ill-posed inverse problems. We prove that deep networks are unstable in a broad class of inverse problems. Our results provide a classification theory of stability and instability of deep networks. Our results also suggest that the instability of deep networks is closely related to the ill-posedness of the corresponding inverse problems. Our results are expected to have a significant impact on the theory of deep learning and inverse problems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of these is the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This article discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that is often cited as evidence for this inability. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time. They are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The causative agent of a reactional condition known as Lucio’s phenomenon, M. lepromatosis is an uncultured pathogen. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a Mexican patient. We found that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae have retained many functions required to infect the peripheral nervous system. Phylogenetic analyses suggest that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA than M. leprae. These findings have implications for leprosy treatment and the evolution of the leprosy pathogens. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. The entanglement dynamics is a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. However, a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems is still missing. Here, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions. We check our result against numerical data. Our work provides a solid foundation for the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems. It also opens the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems beyond the space–time scaling limit.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is not suitable for mass vaccination due to its high cost. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is temperature sensitive in vitro but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. This vaccine candidate is highly attenuated, has a short incubation period, and is protective in hamsters. This vaccine candidate is suitable for mass vaccination.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of the disease and its impact on human populations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known phenomenon in biology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our findings also have implications for the evolution of brain size and neuronal density in humans.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and cancer cells have evolved metabolic adaptations to survive and proliferate. The metabolic phenotype of cancer cells is influenced by the tumor microenvironment, and by the cancer-associated mutations in the cell. In this study, we show that the mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 regulates the metabolic phenotype of cancer cells. Our data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic basis for the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. Our findings also suggest that TRAP1 may be a useful target for cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in many cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. ADF is also involved in diseases, such as cancer and fibrosis. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin filaments is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of ADF’s function in cells. They also provide a platform for developing new therapies for diseases caused by ADF dysfunction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fructose, a sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is widely used in the United States. However, the effects of fructose on appetite and food-seeking behavior are unknown. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity. Copyright © 2013. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestries. The settlement history of Madagascar is also complex. We show that Madagascar was colonized by multiple waves of people, and that the settlement of Madagascar was not homogeneous. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in real-world settings. We show that emotional contagion can occur outside of in-person interaction between individuals. This work suggests that in-person interaction is not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also has implications for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a complex machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into proteins. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that the ribosome encounters. In addition to reading mRNA sequences, the ribosome can also read sequences in the coding regions of mRNA. In this study, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can impact the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can impact the rate of protein synthesis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes in older age. These associations are robust to the inclusion of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or to the measurement of outcomes before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. These findings have implications for public health and gerontology. Copyright © 2016. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Aquatic mammals are larger than their terrestrial relatives. This paper tests the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are constrained to a size attractor in the water. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor. The existence of this size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. This work provides a quantitative test of the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are constrained to a size attractor. The common cold is a major cause of lost work and school days, and there is no effective vaccine. The mechanisms that determine the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication are not known. We show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at nasal cavity temperature than at core body temperature. This temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the RIG-I–like receptor signaling pathway. Our findings provide insight into the mechanisms that determine the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication. They also suggest that the antiviral defense response of infected cells may be a potential target for antiviral therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to detect surfaces. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. The pili-mediated surface sensing results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term surface attachment and stimulates additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. Our findings demonstrate that pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model may be a general mechanism for bacteria to sense and respond to environmental signals. Understanding the molecular mechanisms of this sensing system may provide new insights into the pathogenesis of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Pesticide contamination of surface waters is a global problem. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer. We also show that deer can transmit SARS-CoV-2 to other deer. These findings have important implications for the future of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a paradigm in which a system evolves toward a critical state in which the system’s activity is proportional to the frequency of its critical fluctuations. Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe biotic crisis in the last 542 My. Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status. However, their assessments are subjective and categorical. Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for human communication. It is also a highly specialized domain, and it is not clear how the brain supports this ability. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost during development, and the adult CNS is incapable of regenerating. The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Language is a complex cognitive ability that is essential for communication. It is also a highly flexible skill that can be used in a variety of contexts. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. Nutrient pollution is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries draining agricultural and urban landscapes. However, most monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to large water bodies. Our findings have important implications for the design of nutrient management strategies to protect coastal ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. It suggests that the extremization of rare events may be a general principle of nature.

Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use specialized tentacle structures armed with nematocysts for prey capture. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

Modern farm machinery is a key driver of agricultural productivity. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction.
